name_origin.etymology: The name is descriptive Modern Hebrew. 'Kadurei' (כדורי) is the construct state (smichut) of 'Kadurim' (balls), derived from the root K-D-R denoting roundness. 'Shokolad' is a Modern Hebrew loanword adopted from European languages (German 'Schokolade', Yiddish/Russian 'shokolad'), ultimately derived from the Nahuatl 'xocolātl'. This dish is not traditional to North African Jewish cuisine but is a ubiquitous staple of the modern Israeli kitchen (the 'Kibbutz childhood' dessert) that has been adopted by all Jewish communities in Israel, including Djerbans, often replacing traditional labor-intensive sweets.
name_origin.sources_notes: This is a modern culinary term. The dish's popularity in Israel is linked to the austerity period (Tzena) and the widespread availability of 'Petit Beurre' biscuits, influenced by European no-bake desserts like Swedish Chokladbollar or Danish Romkugler.

alternative_names.name: Kadurim
alternative_names.notes: Colloquial shortening used by Israeli children.

alternative_names.name: Boules au chocolat
alternative_names.notes: Likely name used by Francophone North African Jews when adopting this modern dessert.

similar_dishes.name: Chokladbollar
similar_dishes.similarity: No-bake cocoa balls rolled in coconut.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Uses rolled oats as the base instead of crushed biscuits.

similar_dishes.name: Salame di Cioccolato
similar_dishes.similarity: Identical ingredients (crushed tea biscuits, cocoa, butter/sugar).
similar_dishes.key_difference: Shaped into a sausage/log and sliced, rather than rolled into individual balls.

similar_dishes.name: Brigadeiro
similar_dishes.key_difference: Cooked mixture based on condensed milk, not a cold mixture of biscuits and cocoa.

similar_dishes.name: Kaaber Ellouz
similar_dishes.similarity: Traditional sweet balls served at celebrations.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Made from almond paste (marzipan) and sugar, colored with food dye, containing no chocolate or biscuits.
